column2: Obama said at a White House news conference with Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi.Saying ""Mr. Trump rarely surprises me these days
column3: Obama said he was much more concerned to see support for the candidate's stance on Putin and Russia from Republican officials who historically had been anti-Russia.Historically
column4: Republican politicians have often taken or appeared to take a harder line on Russia's predecessor
column6: the United States' Cold War foe.

column1: Obama said Russia's behavior has undermined international norms and said any suggestion that the United States has encroached on Russian interests is wrong.""We think that Russia is a large
column2: important country with a military that is second only to ours and has to be a part of the solution on the world stage rather than part of the problem
column3: Obama said.

column1: But their behavior has undermined international norms and international rules in ways we have to call them out on
column2: Obama said
column3: citing ""Russian aggression in Ukraine"" and other actions.

column1: Russia has been internationally condemned for its 2014 annexation of Crimea from Ukraine and its support of pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine. (Reporting by Ayesha Rascoe

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-cuba-usa-ryan-idUSKCN12I27D	Top Republican pledges to maintain Cuba trade embargo	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The top Republican in the U.S. Congress dimmed hopes that lawmakers might end the embargo on Cuba after President Barack Obama leaves office
column2: saying on Tuesday he intends to keep the trade restrictions in place.""As the past two years of normalizing relations have only emboldened the regime at the expense of the Cuban people
column3: I fully intend to maintain our embargo on Cuba
column4: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan said in a statement.The Obama administration has been easing restrictions on dealings with Cuba since the surprise announcement in 2014 by Obama and Cuban President Raul Castro that the long-time foes would move toward more normal relations.On Friday
column5: the White House announced new measures to further ease trade
column7: including allowing American travelers to bring home more of the country's coveted cigars and rum.

column1: But the half-century-long embargo can only be lifted fully by Congress
column2: which is controlled by Ryan's Republicans. While some join most of Obama's fellow Democrats in backing the new policies
column3: party leaders have opposed legislation to ease restrictions.Some lawmakers had hoped attitudes in Congress might soften after Obama leaves office in January
column4: even if Democrats do not win majorities in the House and Senate
column5: especially with Americans accustomed to two years of freer travel and business.

column1: Cuban relations often come to the fore during U.S. election campaigns. Pro-embargo Cuban-Americans are an important Republican voting bloc in Florida
column2: which often has close congressional races and is one of the swing states that can decide presidential elections.Ryan termed Obama's actions ""efforts to appease the oppressive regime"" in Cuba. He said they would strengthen its government and endanger U.S. companies' intellectual property rights.

column1: Backers of Obama's policy say half a century of restrictions on trade and travel have not ended Cuban communism
column2: and are not worth denying U.S. citizens freedom of travel and U.S. companies the chance to do business there.        (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Alistair Bell)"	['Paul'

column2: not Trump	"

column1: By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Republican U.S. congressional candidates worried that Donald Trump's struggling White House bid will damage them too have seized on one of President Barack Obama's signature foreign policy initiatives to try to ward off Democrats in the Nov 8 elections.With control of the Senate and perhaps even the House of Representatives in the balance
column2: millions of dollars has been spent on campaign advertisements criticizing last year's Iran nuclear pact
column3: even in districts where foreign affairs generally are not a top concern.Although Iran is unlikely to be most voters' main reason for choosing a candidate
column4: strategists said the money could be well spent. Iran provides a distraction for Republicans concerned that the unpopularity of Trump -- whose poll numbers are dropping as he fights off several allegations that he groped women -- could also sink party members further down the ballot.One typical ad
column5: for Iowa Republican Representative Rod Blum
column6: uses apocalyptic imagery to tie Democratic challenger Monica Vernon to the Iran agreement.""Would you give billions to an Islamic Republic that burns our flag and chants 'Death to America?' Monica Vernon would
column7: a male voice thunders over a video montage of marching troops
column8: nuclear weapons and protesters burning U.S. flags.Vernon
column9: a member of the Cedar Rapids City Council
column10: has voiced support for the nuclear deal.Blum's spot is similar to dozens rolled out on behalf of Republican candidates who argue that America's influence is weaker because of Obama and by extension Hillary Clinton
column11: his former secretary of state who is now the Democratic presidential nominee.

column1: Iran is a piece of the national security anxiety people feel
column2: Republican strategist Matt Mackowiak said. ""Foreign policy's really complicated. Average voters don't understand it
column3: don't follow it closely
column4: but they know what bad foreign policy looks like.""POLITICIZED ISSUE

column1: The agreement between Iran
column2: the United States and other world powers curbs Tehran's nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief and the release of frozen Iranian assets.

column1: Trump frequently criticizes the accord and promises to make much better deals
column2: based on his business experience
column3: if he wins the White House.The real estate magnate has hammered the Iran pact in both of his presidential debates with Clinton and it is likely to come up at Wednesday's third debate in Nevada.Reuters/Ipsos polling in May showed Americans preferred Republicans' plans for dealing with Iran by 37 percent versus 21.9 percent for the Democrats'.Every Republican in Congress opposed the Iran breakthrough. Many worried that Obama gave up too much to a country that sponsors terrorism and threatens Israel.

column1: The issue has become more politicized recently
column2: as congressional Republicans denounced the release of cash to Iran as a ""ransom"" payment and charged that huge Boeing Co and Airbus contracts to sell Iran jetliners could support terrorism.In the race for a U.S. Senate seat in North Carolina on Nov. 8
column3: a conservative spending group spent $1 million on advertising attacking Deborah Ross
column4: the Democrat running against incumbent Senator Richard Burr
column5: over the Iran deal.Israel also opposed the Iran accord
column7: the main U.S. pro-Israel lobby group. Support for Israel is important to voters
column8: especially evangelical Christians who are a wellspring of Republican support.There is more election advertising opposing the Iran deal than supporting it
column9: but there is some backing for it.J Street
column12: 000 on advertising attacking Republican Senators Patrick Toomey and Ron Johnson
column13: in tight re-election races in Democratic-leaning Pennsylvania and Wisconsin
column14: for opposing the Iran pact.     (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Alistair Bell)"	['Israel'

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKBN12H1UN	Trump sharpens 'rigged' election allegations disputed by Republican lawyers	"
By Emily Stephenson and Alana Wise
| GREEN BAY
column2: Wis./WASHINGTON

column1: GREEN BAY
column2: Wis./WASHINGTON Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump on Monday cited studies he said showed rampant voter fraud
column3: saying the Nov. 8 election was ""rigged"" against him even as Republican lawyers called his allegations unfounded.Trump
column4: a New York businessman making his first run for public office
column5: has sought to raise fears of a flawed election as he has fallen in opinion polls against Democrat Hillary Clinton.""They even want to try to rig the election at the polling place
column6: Trump told a rally in Green Bay
column7: Wisconsin. ""So many cities are corrupt and voter fraud is very
column8: very common.""Trump cited Pew Trusts research from 2012 that called for updates to the voter registration system because about 24 million registrations were inaccurate. (bit.ly/1HN4uTF)He also referred to a 2014 article by two political scientists in the Washington Post that said non-citizens who voted could have accounted for Democratic victories in a few close elections in 2008
column9: although the authors acknowledged the sample size of their study was small. (wapo.st/1pX17Bf)Numerous studies have shown that voter fraud in U.S. elections is very rare.Republican campaign lawyer Chris Ashby said Trump's charges could foment unrest and were ""unfounded"" and ""dangerous.""""When you say an election is rigged
column13: Ashby said in an interview. ""I think some of Donald Trump's comments could cause unrest at the polls.""Some Republicans have urged Trump to drop the assertions. Early voting and voting by mail have already begun in many states.Mark Braden
column14: partner at Baker and Hostetler and former chief counsel for the Republican National Committee
column15: said that any sort of election rigging at the national level ""just is impossible
column16: citing the various systems in place that would make such an endeavor complicated and unfeasible. ""Our system is principally a system based upon each side watching the other side
column17: Braden said in an interview. ""Our system is dependent on local volunteer participation. Our system has worked very well because we have people who get involved in the process and perform these functions.""Trump also pounced on the release on Monday of Federal Bureau of Investigation documents that he alleged showed ""felony corruption.""The documents cited an FBI official as saying a senior State Department official sought to pressure the bureau in 2015 to drop its insistence that an email from Clinton's private server contained classified information..

column1: Clinton's decision to use a private server while secretary of state from 2009 to 2013 has drawn criticism that she was careless with national security.""This is worse than Watergate
column2: what's going on with this
column3: said Trump.He also proposed a package of ethics reforms
column4: saying that if elected he would ban his administration officials from lobbying government for five years after leaving government.'NOT GOING TO BE RIGGED'

column1: Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook said Trump's assault on the voting system was an act of desperation.""He knows he's losing and is trying to blame that on the system. This is what losers do
column2: Mook told reporters.

column1: The RealClearPolitics average of national opinion polls shows Clinton currently leading Trump by 7.1 percentage points
column2: at 46 percent to 38.9 percent.The country's top elected Republican
column3: House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan
column4: tried to counter Trump's message about election fraud. Spokeswoman AshLee Strong said Ryan ""is fully confident the states will carry out this election with integrity."" In the traditionally hard-fought state of Ohio
column7: said concerns about widespread voter fraud were simply not justified. ""I can reassure Donald Trump: I am in charge of elections in Ohio and they're not going to be rigged
column9: Ohio Secretary of State Jon Husted told CNN. In a report titled ""The Truth About Voter Fraud
column10: the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University School of Law cited voter fraud incident rates between 0.00004 percent and 0.0009 percent.An August study by the Washington Post found 31 credible cases of impersonation fraud out of more than 1 billion votes cast in elections from 2000 to 2014. Arizona State University studies in 2012 and 2016 found similarly low rates.

column1: A number of Republican-led states
column2: citing the need to prevent voter fraud

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-wallstreet-idUSKBN12H2LV	Rejecting Trump
column2: Wall Street Republican donors scatter largesse	"

column1: By Lawrence Delevingne and Svea Herbst-Bayliss
| NEW YORK/BOSTON
NEW YORK/BOSTON Largely united in their dislike of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump
column2: some ultra-wealthy U.S. investors who play in conservative politics are warily weighing their choices
column3: torn between third-party candidates
column4: simply focusing on down-ballot contests or even voting for Democrat Hillary Clinton.As Clinton's lead over Trump has grown in opinion polls
column5: some hedge fund managers who have traditionally donated big money to Republican presidential candidates see the congressional elections as their best hope.Stanley Druckenmiller
column6: one of the best-performing hedge fund managers of all time
column7: told Reuters he had recently given to Republican candidates for Congress in the hope of creating a ""firewall"" against Clinton's economic policies
column8: including more government control of healthcare and what he described as ""astronomical disincentives"" to invest.Druckenmiller
column9: who invests privately since closing his hedge fund firm in 2010
column10: said Trump had an ""unstable personality"" that ruled him out as a candidate.""I might just vote on the down ballot part of the ticket and not bother with the top
column11: he said.Public filings show Druckenmiller donated to U.S. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida in August and the National Republican Congressional Committee in March.He disavowed long-shot Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson
column12: saying he was ""out the window"" after a couple of high-profile lapses on foreign affairs
column13: including struggling to name an international leader he admired.

column1: But some Republican hedge fund managers contacted by Reuters said they planned to vote for Johnson
column2: who is polling in the single digits.Among them is Tiger Management founder Julian Robertson
column3: according to spokesman Fraser Seitel. Robertson previously backed Republicans Jeb Bush and John Kasich.""I've heard from a lot of people who say they'll vote for Johnson or not vote at all because they don't want to be held responsible for having elected Hillary Clinton
column4: one hedge fund billionaire said in describing industry views.The person
column5: who requested anonymity because they did not want their political views to be public
column6: plans to vote for Clinton. The person believes Clinton is the lesser of two evils and that no vote

column1: Other conservative investors focused on congressional races instead of the next president include Cliff Asness of AQR Capital Management and Paul Singer of Elliott Management
column2: according to people familiar with the situation.Asness recently gave to the National Republican Senatorial Committee (NRSC) and a political action committee supporting Pennsylvania Senator Patrick Toomey
column3: according to public filings.Singer has also given to the NRSC
column4: in addition to Together Holding Our Majority PAC
column5: which recently sent money to two Republican senators
column6: John McCain of Arizona and Richard Burr of North Carolina.Asness and Singer declined to comment. Spokespersons for Trump
column7: Clinton and Johnson did not respond to a request for comment.

column1: To be sure
column2: Trump retains a band of loyal hedge fund industry boosters. They include Robert Mercer of Renaissance Technologies and economic advisers Anthony Scaramucci of SkyBridge Capital
column3: John Paulson of Paulson & Co
column4: Stephen Feinberg of Cerberus Capital Management and Steven Mnuchin of Dune Capital Management. Mercer and Scaramucci have re-affirmed their support of Trump in public statements over the last week.Other investors have moved firmly into the Democratic camp: Billionaire Seth Klarman of Baupost Group and Boaz Weinstein of Saba Capital Management are among investors who recently gave Clinton money after years of donations to candidates from both parties. Weinstein declined to comment and Klarman told Reuters in August that Trump is ""completely unqualified for the highest office in the land."" Attitudes against Trump have hardened since multiple women have accused him of groping them and the release of a 2005 video in which he boasts about such behavior. Trump has denied the accusations and has said his comments were just ""locker room talk.""One Republican hedge fund industry veteran said that his peers' revulsion with Trump has become so strong that they feel they have to vote for Clinton - if only to prevent the Republican nominee from winning. ""She at least represents predictability and seasoning
column5: the person said. ""The difference between her and Trump is no contest."" (Reporting by Lawrence Delevingne and Svea Herbst-Bayliss; Editing by Leslie Adler)"	['Clinton'
